title: Miss Lilli  - The Swedish agility dog of the year 2016
description: For the third time Lilli got the title "The Swedish Agility dog of the Year", this after 3,5 years of competing. Lilli is such a clever, silly, fun and talented dog - a special girl! In this video I have mixed some different runs from the year. She also won the Swedish qualifications, qualified for Crufts, won the Swedish championship and got one silver and one bronze medal at European open. A pretty good year for us :)

title: Lotus, still going strong!
description:
The old World Champion Lotus, now 14 yrs, is still going strong! 11 days ago he got lost in the wood and spent 18 hrs in the cold snow by him self. No big deal for Lotus, he wasn't affected at all and he didn't really understand the great stir about his long walk... ;o) Thank you all people who cared about us and helped me to find him again!
Lotus is a very special dog for me. Not only for his performances and results but also for his great personality!

title: The Best Time To Ditch That Dog Bowl
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Have you ever wondered how you can use your dog뗩 food for training? 

Maybe you뗬e heard of Ditch the Bowl or rewards-based training, but you뗬e never quite understood HOW using your dog뗩 food for training actually gets the results you want?

In today뗩 AbsoluteDogsTV episode, we are going to take you on a whistle-stop Ditch the Bowl tour, whilst working with a super cute puppy in her very first training session!

So WHY Ditch the Bowl?

1. Think of your dog뗩 food as a pot of value - value that you can use throughout each and every day as training rewards to reinforce your dog뗩 great choices!

2. Ditch the Bowl can be started at any time, any age and any training stage and it뗩 a strategy that will set your dog up for real-life results success, no matter your training struggles! 

3. Whether you have a 랁oodie dog or a dog that couldn뗪 care less amount their meals, Ditch the Bowl helps grow value in food rewards AND value in working WITH YOU!

With the tips in this AbsoluteDOGS TV episode, you will be able to start your dog뗩 Ditch the Bowl journey with confidence and create joyful, fun and reinforcing reward experiences for your dog so that you can start using their daily food for real-life training transformation success!

PLUS! Check out our FREE Ditch the Bowl eBook for everything you could ever need to know about ditching the bowl with your dog!

title: Handling Rough Play The Right Way With Your Dog
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Does your dog play roughly with other dogs and what can you do to encourage your dog in the play the right way?

If you find yourself saying, Oh, he needs to be corrected, to another dog뗩 owner when your dog is being inappropriate, this may be just the episode for you!

Dogs don뗪 always come wired to have the most appropriate communication skills with other dogs. These skills or natural inclinations can be shaped by the environment, by other dogs theyre exposed to, as well as simply their natural energy and commitment to the party to be had!

Most of the time a dog that is over the top about playing with other dogs can appear confident and yet, actually, theyre lacking confidence in the interaction which is why theyre being inappropriate.

Nifty, a young, rough playing Border Collie demonstrates her desire for FLAIR, while we talk you through our top tips. Working on a specific 랋roblem (i.e. rough housing) doesn뗪 always require putting your dog in the situation so that they could possibly fail Youre going to find light bulbs galore in this episode.

title: Stop My Dog Pulling On Leash During My Walks
description:
Does your dog pull on lead? Do they bog off as soon as you unclip their harness or spend the entire walk pretending you don뗪 actually exist?

In today뗩 AbsoluteDogsTV episode, we are going to dive into our top tips to help you set your dog up for success and STOP them pulling on leash during your walks!

So how do you achieve that lovely loose-leash walking dream you뗬e been waiting for?

1. Spend your dog's daily pot of value to grow value in hanging around you and to deliver awesome rewards in your proximity!

2. Play games and have strategies in place to make sure your dog's brain is WITH YOU when you step out the door for a walk!

3. Grow your dog's disengagement skills so that they learn the vital skill that the environment and all the exciting, distracting things it has on offer are actually none of their business!

With the tips in this AbsoluteDOGS TV episode, you뗣l be on the right track to realise your dog owning and dog walking dreams in no time, PLUS we뗬e also got you covered with a challenge that will absolutely transform your walks!

title: Sheep Chasing
description:
Does your dog love to chase? Do they struggle being around anything that moves? You are not alone! In this episode, our very own Lauren Langman, a top dog trainer and agility champion, opens up about her current struggles with her adolescent Border Collie, Nifty. One of those struggles? Nifty wants to chase, chase, chase! 

Whether it's sheep (that's Nifty's preference), squirrels, other critters, cars, or even people and dogs outside of your window, it can be so hard to know the path forward. Don't you worry. In this episode, we share what we've done when our dogs have struggled. Sometimes, the first foot forward isn't always the most obvious solution. In fact, instinctually, we often want to try to solve the problem by focusing on that specific context... We'll give you a hint (the rest is in the podcast, so definitely have a listen!)... 

Training IN the situation, when your dog's brain isn't responsive, isn't the best solution! Dog trainers dogs aren't perfect either. In fact, our dogs are some of our best educators. We share what works so that you don't have to go through the troubleshooting steps - you can skip to the good part... the results.
tags: ['dog training', 'dog trainer', 'dog training advice', 'dog training tips', 'stop dogs chasing']

Cathy joins us to share her amazing Pro Dog Trainer journey - going from a fashion jewellery designer in London, with long commutes and a stressful daily grind, all the way through to making that all-important decision to change her life for the better, fan the flames of her passion for dogs and animals and jump into something that would make her life-changing dream a reality  the Pro Dog Trainer program!

Cathy뗩 journey is absolutely inspiring. It뗩 one of joy, passion, designing her own days and living a healthier life with less stress AND getting to help other dog owners take their dog training struggles and turning them into exciting, real-life results success!

This isn뗪 just a success story, it뗩 one of those feel good and utterly amazing stories that we NEEDED to share with you!

title: Has Your Dog Just Got Into... Hunting?
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Does your dog like to hunt real and imaginary critters? 

In today뗩 AbsoluteDogsTV episode, were covering our top tips for combatting your dog뗩 랃unt struggles. Some dogs are more prone to wanting to hunt than others given their genetic makeup and the behaviours they뗬e rehearsed throughout their lives. 

Did you know that, even for a dog bred to hunt, you can channel that behaviour in a different (much healthier) way so that your dog is meeting their biological needs and yet also not rehearsing undesirable behaviours that are really frustrating when you뗛 prefer focus, engagement and value in YOU. 

Put a training plan in place and plan your next three weeks! Your dog will become what they rehearse. Being mindful of allowing them access to the opportunities when your dog doesn뗪 have the skillset to make the right choice can make training progress much slower. Speed up your success with the top tips we share in today뗩 episode!

title: Dog Training and Fitness are the Perfect Match
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Dog training is a great way to add fitness to your day! 

Your dog training should be fun, not frustrating and the really cool thing is that most training involves getting you moving. 

Fitness is all about getting your steps in (even if youre not wearing a step counter, the steps still count!). Were all about finding easy wins to help propel us toward establishing great habits. 

Have you ever set a big fitness goal and as soon as you miss a step, miss a day, getting back to achieving that goal can feel insurmountable! Were all about fitting things into our day while combining activities to get the most out of our day and your dog will love to get in some steps with you. Turn your dog training into a fitness opportunity for you. It does count and it doesn뗪 even feel like your 랂etting your steps in. 

Let us know in the comments, what are your favourite games to play that help you get your steps in? Is there a game from our channel that you are going to give a try this week that will give you an easy fitness win?

title: DON'T rest those aching joints?!
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Is your dog 6 years or older? After six years of age, their body can start to compensate for age and more! It can be easy to recognise a dog뗩 slowing down and resting to be a natural part of the ageing process But we have some news! 

DON뗎 rest those aching joints! It뗩 so vital to your dog뗩 physical wellness (and even behavioural wellness) to keep them moving, to keep them feeling great. Taking care to provide them with what they need to keep their body loose, joints supple and reduce stiffness and soreness through movement. 

Because dog뗩 lose fitness quite quickly, a good question to ask is Is resting the right choice right now? What are we resting? 

You can get ahead of the game with joint supplements for your dog with quality, specially formulated supplement, as well as providing your dog with the exercise best suited for them as an individual. Today뗩 is supercharged with tips on how you can keep your dog뗩 body in tip top shape.

title: Sexier Than A Squirrel Podcast: Train Your Dog Like A Pro!
description:
The world is facing a shortage of dog trainers - specifically dog trainers equipped to deliver long-lasting, real-life results with an aversive-free approach. No cookie cutter strategies, but instead trainers able to adapt and modify their plan based on the unique needs of the dog in front of them - something that games-based trainers and concept trainers are able to do - and yet there is a big need for more games-based trainers to do what they do best. Could this be you?

 You may be thinking, There뗩 no way! Someone is more qualified.. Every dog trainer starts somewhere and if you are passionate about working with animals, working with dogs, you already have an incredible foundation to propel you to further dog training success. Have you already begun to homeschool your own dog? You can go from being a pro for your own dog to being a pro for dogs that truly need your passion to transform their lives. 

Many dog owners are facing behaviour struggles with their dogs and are having a difficult time finding a trainer able to meet their dog where theyre at. This could even be you! 

Do you already have a dog with behaviour struggles but youre not quite sure where to turn? Have you sought out a trainer, perhaps even had one come to your home or you뗬e travelled to them, and you뗬e walked away from the session feeling worse than at the start  Perhaps there were glimmers of hope, the behaviour stopped, but the path to get there, the strategies required to stop your dog뗩 behaviour, didn뗪 feel right. Listen to your gut! 

The time is now. Train like a pro for yourself, for your own dog, and immerse yourself in something that has you feeling energised, passionate and excited!  Stay tuned for next week뗩 epic episode focused on something pretty spectacular that will give you your passion an exciting outlet.

title: THE solution to stopping your dog pulling on lead
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Does your dog pull on lead? We are here to tell you the top TWO skills that your dog will need in order to relieve that tension on the lead and give you a dog that walks politely, in every environment! 

What is skill #1?
Your dog needs to know that they should be paying attention to you from the very start. Whether your dog has a history of rehearsing ignoring you on every walk or they check out when distractions are more tempting, but are great when distractions aren뗪 around, this is a skill they absolutely need. Choosing you is #1 and Orientation Game will get you there!

Your dog needs to know WHERE they need to be! Believe it or not, telling them verbally or via the leash isn뗪 clear communication. Instead, top up the value in your proximity to make the best deal for them the most obvious one. We show you a fun, easy, effective game focusing on proximity.

title: My Dog is Struggling With Calmness
description:

Strategies to consider for your dog:

Is there a reason your dog chooses other things over calmness?
How can the environment or their routine be adjusted temporarily to set them up for success?
Measure your progress day to day, recognising the small wins just as much as you celebrate the more obvious wins
Are their daily activities that might be contributing to high energy choices?
Have you provided your dog with a space to anchor them, to ground them?

title: Using Your Food for Training Young or New Dogs
description:
Have you welcomed a new puppy or young dog into your home and want to start their training journey off on the right paw?

Using food is one of the many ways you can reward your dog when you play games! We like to use our dog's daily food allowance as rewards by ditching the food bowl to start building our relationship and training journey.

When working with a puppy or young dog, we need to consider a few things to ensure that we are utilising their food in a way they can make sense of it.  For example, considering how well developed our puppy or young dogs' eye sight is before attempting to teach them how to catch or how far to bowl a piece of food out for them will help us set the training session up for success.

Dive into this action packed episode for more tips and tricks for using your dogs' daily food allowance as rewards!

title: Training Your Dog With Toys
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

How to begin training your dog using toys. Some dogs love toys, while for others, you will need a grow that desire to play with toys.

Why use toys? If you have a toy with you while out on a walk or playing at the park that you know your dog loves, you can use that object to help keep your dog with you instead of them investigating a squirrel, chasing a bicycle or running off with another dog.

Choose toys that suit your dog and toys that encourage play around you, rather than away from you. Animate them, keep the games simple, make it a fun experience for your dog and of course, let them win!

TOP TIPS:

1. Animate the toy  move it around like it is a little animal. Use your dog뗩 prey drive!

2. Use toys with length  to allow your dog to play pressure-free

3. Choose toys that your dog loves  experiment to discover your dog뗩 favourite

4. Remove toys to add value  If your dog is not playing with a toy, remove it to make a valuable resource

5. Toy play should be rule free  let your dog drive the game

6. Choose toys and games appropriate for your dog and their life stage

7. Grow your dog뗩 desire for toys  short sessions with no pressure, no rules, just lots of amazing fun.

Do you own a dog that chases, hunts or stalks other dogs, people, cars or wildlife? Learn how to harness that desire using toys and concept games-based training. Grab your free eBook today https://game.absolute-dogs.com/chase44201350

title: STAS: Introducing Dogs To One Another
description:
How can you introduce dogs to each other?

In today's podcast episode, we are diving into safely introducing dogs and the considerations you can have in mind as you work toward introducing a new dog into your home or dogs that may be spending time together. 

How can your emotions and behaviour have an impact
What can you do if you feel you aren't confident in orchestrating the introduction
Identifying whether your dog is ready or prepared for an introduction
Setting the scene to maintain safety and allow freedom of communication

Making sure you have considered the set up and the process of preparing them for the interaction gradually. We provide examples (including with other animals!). 

There are so many situations where knowing the best approach is essential to the success of the introduction. There is no rush and be sure to have safe guards in place that ensure the introduction happens in the way you want it to vs. a spontaneous interaction that occurs due to a failure of set up, such as a barrier breakdown, etc. 

Introducing your new puppy to an adult or senior dog, into a multi-animal and multi-dog household, as well as introducing a new rescue or rehome into your home can go smoothly when you're able to set the energy, set the expectations, and minimise the opportunity for poor decisions. 

Every situation will flex dependent on the variables and some dogs will require much slower introductions than others. Listen in for our top tips to introducing dogs and let us know what you think!

title: Being Brave: A Tale of Injury, Courage and Love
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

Brave is THE MOST brilliant Border Collie, best friend and companion, sweet family dog and a fan of doing literally anything and everything where she gets to have fun. She has featured in many of our AbsoluteDog뗩 videos, has inspired thousands of dog owners all over the world with her sweet passion and genuinely kind connection.

In September 2020, Brave was badly injured in a completely unforeseen freak accident and experienced what뗩 known as an ANNPE (acute non-compressive nucleus pulposus extrusion), something completely unavoidable, life changing and horribly unexpected. Join us as we celebrate the incredible journey that Brave has taken with the support of her very own team including Lauren Langman, and the amazing professionals that surround them both.

Life can change in an instant and dog뗩 can teach us so many things within those special moments - to be present, to keep moving, to stay in a positive state and most of all, to Be Brave

Brave뗩 journey includes family heart ache, her special journey, her varied canine physical rehabilitation, various setbacks and progressions forward, and vital information for anyone facing a similar situation with their own dog and wondering how to move forward.

Let뗩 take a moment to show gratitude to the world and most of all to step up and Be Brave.

title: STAS:  Training Your Family
description:

Setting really clear expectations is important with family members to set your dog up for success (and you!). Let뗩 face it, it can be really frustrating when everyone has their own opinions and thoughts on how training should happen and what is acceptable and what isn뗪 acceptable.

Enforcing your expectations
Providing a cost (what is the consequence if they do something you don뗪 want or do want) and
Shaping them into interacting with your dog in the best way

are all really key strategies with family and friends.

In today뗩 podcast episode, we talk about how you can be prepared for when situations arise where your dog may be interacting with others. Many common behaviour struggles are a result of unclear expectations of both the people and the dog.

Are you sharing space in your home? 
How can you guide the experience for the best outcome?

title: How to Train Your Border Collie
description:
In this week뗩 AbsoluteDogs TV Episode, we discuss:

title: STAS: When You're Feeling Frustrated, Disappointed and Like There's No Hope
description:
In this week뗩 episode, we discuss: When You're Feeling Frustrated, Disappointed and Like There's No Hope

There are two types of training 

1) Training in the Situation  trying to teach your dog in the moment, when theyre behaviour is undesirable and at its height.
2) Training FOR the situation  preparing your dog for the situation beforehand so they have the skills to handle the situation without rehearsing the behaviour you are looking to stop and for which you are seeking a solution.

It뗩 important to know what skills you need to work on so that you can prepare yourself and your dog for the situation. Knowing the ingredients so that you can discover your dog뗩 recipe for behaviour transformation is so, so key. We dive into this in today뗩 episode!

title: Are You Poisoning Your Dog's Name?
description:
In this week뗩 video, we cover: Are You Poisoning Your Dog뗩 Name?

Did you know that you can poison a cue? What does that mean?

A poisoned cue is a cue that has developed a negative association for your dog. What are some ways you can be accidentally poisoning your recall cue?

Calling their name when something unpleasant is about to happen such as:

 The fun is over and their off-leash freedom is going to end
 Theyre in the garden and are called inside where nothing fun awaits them
 Nail trims, bath time, or they grabbed by their collar

However, you can become the master of recall games that can prevent a poisoned cue from ever happening. Whether you rebuild your existing poisoned cue or come up with a new one entirely, we explore a game in today뗩 video that is sure to get you on the right path, no matter your dog뗩 breed, age, or size!

title: STAS: You Can't Catch Me!
description:
In this week뗩 episode, we discuss: You Can뗪 Catch Me! Dog Recall Struggles

The recall struggle is real! Dogs are creative and really amazing at discovering patterns in the day-to-day. Things like:

  Clipping the lead on at the end of the walk meaning the fun is over
 The leash coming out when a dog or human is spotted in the difference!
 The leash coming off is FREEDOM (and no value in staying close to their owner)  

Many of us have experienced this struggle and part of being an a flexible, resourceful Gamechanger is embracing the games-based approach with games that truly speak to the motivations behind your dog뗩 behaviour. 

In today뗩 episode, we dive into some really impactful games and strategies that will help you come out on the other side of this struggle with real-life results AND a dog that suddenly gets excited when the leash comes out anywhere and everywhere. 

We뗛 love to know how you get on. Share your experience with us, as well as a review! Your success is important to us! 

In this podcast, we mentioned our biothane longlines. You can get those and more here: https://shop.absolutedogstraining.com/product/absolutedogs-biothane-long-lines/

title: How To Deal With Your Dog Growling Around Bones, Food and Toys!
description:
In this week뗩 video, we cover: How to Deal with Growling and Bones!

Does your dog have a hard time when they have something valuable, such as a bone? There is always a game for that! Today we talk on how you can get your dog to move away from something delicious without any conflict whatsoever! 

What does that mean? That means NO GROWLY behaviour!

There is no need to take things from your dog, especially if that뗩 been part of your dog뗩 relationship with bones in the past. If they think it will get taken away, they are more likely to show that growly behaviour we don뗪 want to see. 

Watch this episode as we talk you through a more cooperative, and safe, way to handle these situations where you need your dog to come away from a bone. 

Observe three dogs, ALL at the same time, enjoy some meaty, yummy bones and get to see just how you can create a safer relationship-enhancing approach through games-based training.

title: STAS: My Neighbour Hates My Dog
description:
In this week뗩 episode, we discuss: My neighbour hates my dog!

It뗩 not uncommon for neighbours to express frustration when they can hear barking, whining, howling, and more! You are not alone, and we have solutions for you. There are things you can do, and there are people out there that share the same struggle. 

In this episode we share our top tips on how you can help to create a more pleasant experience for yourself and for your neighbour. 

If your dog뗩 behaviour isn뗪 as you want it to be, a great strategy would be to limit the amount of time they can spend rehearsing naughty behaviour. 

Giving yourself a realistic timeline to work on growing great decision-making skills on your dog뗩 part is key. It won뗪 happen next week, and yet you can see progress and you can have a plan in place for when you can뗪 make sure your dog is employing themselves properly. 

We explore how to balance responsibility depending on your dog뗩 skill set and so much more. Let us know what you think and don뗪 forget to share a review. We love hearing from our listeners.

title: STAS: My Dog Hates Me
description:
This week we discuss: My Dog Hates Me

Does your dog struggle with going to the vet, having their nails trimmed, or just being handled in general? We know that sometimes things must happen and that can definitely withdraw from our relationship bank account with our dogs. 

What is the relationship bank account? 

It뗩 the way we go through life with our dogs. This bank account can have investments and withdrawals. Investments are positive interactions, like playing games from the Sexier than a Squirrel 25-Day Challenge. 

Withdrawals are negative interactions and experiences that your dog does not enjoy like ear treatments, punishment in training, etc. 

We are talking on how to top up your relationship bank account even if there are withdrawals  to truly balance it out with so many more investments. 

Learn about:

 Predictors AND how they influence your dog
 What you can to make predictable events less predictable
 How you can replenish your relationship bank account with your dog
 How little daily actions can have such a positive impact

title: STAS: Imposter Syndrome
description:
This week we discuss: Imposter Syndrome

No matter whether you are a dog owner, aspiring dog trainer, or a professional dog trainer, this very much applies to you. 

What is imposter syndrome? This is when, in any facet of your life, you doubt your skills, talents, or accomplishments. No matter that the world keeps telling you that you are quite in the right place, that your experience and skills are valued, you might interpret those confirmations of your abilities to only be the case because you뗬e somehow deceived those around you in believing that you are capable. 

You are exactly who you need to be. You are the very best you that you can be you. You are absolutely crushing it. 

In today뗩 episode we go through some super top tips that we apply in our own lives, to kicking imposter syndrome to the curb, and to continue being the awesome human being that you already are. 

Supercharge your day and listen to an episode that will surely give you the optimism boost you need. You뗬e got this!

title: Top Tips For A Stress Free Walk Part 2!
description:
In this week뗩 video, we cover: Top Tips for A Stress-Free Walk Part 2

This is a multi-part series! This is Part 2!

Are you ready for training exercises and games that will help your dog truly earn and enjoy off leash freedom?

In today뗩 video we explore the Double Clip Game. Being off lead shouldn뗪 be a huge event for your dog. You don뗪 want your dog to bolt off as soon as you clip your dog off leash. 

We discuss fading food reinforcement based on where your dog is at in their journey. There are different stages and knowing how you can support your dog best in their journey is so, so key. 

Predictability can lead to frustration and over excitement. Changing it up, making certain parts of the walk on lead vs. off lead, playing the games that target proximity, and more can help you achieve off leash freedom. 

Magma and Abra demonstrate off leash freedom with one dog, as well as two dogs. What can you do to get real-life results and stress-free walks (on or off leash)?

title: STAS: 7 Years Old Plus Dog? Listen to This!
description:
This week we discuss: How we can support our senior dogs?

As our dogs age, their bodies change, as do their minds. In this episode, we want to empower dog owners around the world to take charge of their senior dog뗩 care and to take action in reducing (and sometimes even reversing) the symptoms of ageing. 

We have experienced ageing dogs in our own homes, and we are all too aware of the changes that can occur. Our once spry, joyful, and alert dogs can become a little stiffer, sleep more, wake more at odd hours, or even appear to be less joyful in their interactions with us. 

Our own senior dogs inspired us to grow our knowledge. What can you do to support your senior dog? We dive deeper into cognitive changes, as well as physical changes, and include some great learning, as well as some implementable strategies so that you too can help support your dog as they enter their senior years. 

Not only are there a lot of things you can do day to day that will help your dog; there are also some great ways to support your senior dog nutritionally. Empower yourself and other senior dog owners by listening in and sharing this immense episode with any owners you know may benefit.

title: Top Tips For A Stress Free Walk Without Lead Pulling!!
description:
In this week뗩 video, we cover: Top Tips for A Stress-Free Walk Without Lead Pulling

This is a multi-part series! This is Part 1!

When your dog pulls on lead, chases critters, sniffs anything and everything, it can be frustrating. One of the larger questions we can get asked with this very common struggle is: How do I even get started?

We are covering some top tips on how to STOP bad behaviour on your walks with some easy, implementable strategies that will help you and your dog achieve less stressful walks. 

Before you even start your walk, what do you want your walk to look like?

Some top tips include more coaching on:

 Starting as you mean to go on
 Avoiding nagging your dog!
 Equipping yourself and your dog appropriately for their level of training
 What kind of energy should you have on your walk?
 What should you be aware of when you are on your walk?
 How do you respond to sudden changes in the environment?
 Reinforcement strategies aren뗪 always the same for every dog!

 What does your dog love? Make your walk bespoke to you and your dog.

title: STAS: Pandemic Puppies?
description:
This week we discuss: Pandemic Puppies

As a result of the changes in the world in the past year, there are many shy dogs and pandemic puppies that have had limited exposure. Is limited exposure the end of the world, is that a bad thing, or is it potentially not such a bad thing?

We know that empowering your dog through games can help prepare them for life. One bad event outweighs even 100 positive events. The key to having a puppy that is cool, calm, and collected in the world is quality over quantity. 

Interaction vs. Being in the Presence of is a HUGE thing to consider when exploring socialisation with your Pandemic Puppy. In addition, growing concepts prepares your dog far more than a checklist. There are so many top tips in this episode and if you have a pandemic puppy or know someone that does, this is the episode for you (and share away!).

title: Neuter Your Dog to Stop Barking, Reactivity and Jumping Up?!
description:
In this week뗩 video, we cover: Neutering to stop jumping up, barking, and more? 

Is barking, jumping, even aggression or fearful behaviour, helped when a dog is neutered? According to a 2018 study, it뗩 not! Wow, right?

What can be stopped? Urinating in the house and howling when left alone 

Tom, a veterinary behaviourist, and top dog trainer is talking on neutering to prevent or stop problem behaviours in dogs in this jampacked episode of AbsoluteDogsTV.

This is NOT about population control, but instead this is about responsible dog owners like you that have been advised to neuter your dog and youre not sure if it뗩 the right thing to do. 

So much information is out there, and this is an important video to share. Even if you have neutered your dog, it뗩 not too late! There are some exercises (super fun games!) you can play to combat the neuter.

What can you, as an empowered dog owner, do to make the most informed decision for your dog?

title: STAS: Creating Food Drive in your Dog
description:
Sexier Than A Squirrel Podcast: Creating Food Drive in Your Dog

This week we discuss: Creating Food Drive in your Dog! 

Let뗩 talk about creating a food driven dog! We get hundreds, thousands, of emails asking how to take a dog that lacks motivation for food and grow them into a truly food driven dog. We뗬e got super solutions for you and this episode is jam packed! 

It뗩 all about creating an experience for you and your dog. As with anything, focus on progress, not perfection. This can be a gradual progression and that뗩 okay! Measure your progress by focusing on you and your dog as a team. Everyone will have their own journey. It뗩 easy to want to compare, and yet your journey with your dog is an adventure that will be unique to you. 

We provide answers to all the great questions our students most often ask when wanting to encourage more food drive in their dog. Hop on and listen now for the insights that will help you begin creating food drive today.

title: Nightmare Vet Visits! Barking, Jumping Up, Craziness!
description:
In this week뗩 video, we cover: Nightmare Vet Visits! Barking, Jumping Up, Craziness!

Did you know that Tom is a Veterinarian? In today뗩 episode, we get some great top tips from Tom on how you can prepare your dog for vet visits with minimal stress! Sometimes the experience is very much what it is and you can뗪 control every variable 

However, you can go into taking your dog to the vet and provide really clear information to your dog so that the experience can be more predictable for them, and thus, less stressful. 

How can you make sure your dog does as well as possible when they go to the vet? Is your dog afraid of the vet? You can prepare them by working on handling, including nails for nail trims, handling that can prepare them for a vaccination appointment, and more. 

What if your dog hates the car ride there? With this video you can grow some strategies to safeguard your dog뗩 emotional state. 

Are you ready to help the vet experience a fun experience for your dog?

title: How to prepare your dog for MUZZLE TRAINING!
description:
Believe it or not, muzzle training can benefit your dog in so many ways, even if you may not realise your dog may need it! There are countries that require it as a guideline, for veterinary examinations in the case of an injury or accident etc. It뗩 better to be prepared, just in case. 

In today뗩 video, we show you The Cone Game! This is a great game to introduce muzzle training to your dog. What뗩 really cool is this is a great optimism and confidence boosting game too! 

Step 1. 
Present the Cone to your dog!

Step 2. 
Reward any interaction with the cone (looking at, sniffing, moving toward) by feeding away from the cone. If your dog is struggling, feed near the cone. Train the dog in front of you. 

The video offers some troubleshooting tips and gives insight into how it might look with an inexperienced dog vs. an experienced dog. You뗣l see the difference right away. We do add a bit more of a challenge to the game! Dive and start having fun!

title: STAS: Being A Leader Of Your Dog
description:

To really unlock real-life transformations, to unlock next-level relationship, look after both ends of this lead! This means YOU, just as much as you look after your dog. This will allow you to get the momentum that you need to really transform their behaviour for the better.

title: STAS: The Naughty But Nice Revolution
description:
The Sexier Than A Squirrel Podcast: THE NAUGHTY BUT NICE REVOLUTION
Is your dog뷕

 A barking, lunging mess at the end of the lead
 Worried or scared
 Easily distracted
 Out of control
 Hyper
 A dog who struggles to settle
 A dog who is into everything, stealing food, you name it!
 A dog who destroys things
 Over the top excited
 A dog who loves everything a bit too much

If the answer is yes to any of the above, then you guessed it, you own a Naughty But Nice dog!

We뗣l let you in on a secret, WE have owned naughty but nice dogs. We know what it뗩 like to feel stressed, embarrassed, guilty and all of those conflicting emotions that bubble up when owning a Naughty But Nice dog. 

In this week뗩 episode we take a moment to celebrate all of the Naughty But Nice dogs out there. As we want to tell you one thing and that is THERE IS ALWAYS HOPE. So, embrace your dog and know that your current struggles can be turned into strengths. 

We look forward to sharing with you just how youre going to get started!

title: STAS: Socialisation
description:
This week we discuss: SOCIALISATION 

In this week뗩 podcast we discuss the S word! It뗩 such a hot topic isn뗪 it! For us socialisation is all about building positive, calm associations in the face of distractions like other dogs that are oh so exciting, and to help with this the number one concept that we tackle from day one is disengagement. 

Ensuring your puppy is having lots of good experiences is down to you by setting them up for success (training for the situation, not in the situation) controlling the controllable and knowing when and being OK with saying no as you know your puppy better than anyone else. Take a listen to the podcast for more on this!

title: STAS: Should You Walk Your Dog?
description:
The Sexier Than A Squirrel Podcast: Should You Walk Your Dog?

We뗬e all heard of those suggestions which tell us how long you should walk your dog and how often. Truth bomb! They are all made up! 

In times like this where parts of the world are on lockdown and social distancing is a must, this is a great question to ask!

We get that society and lots of training books are normally telling us to take our dogs for daily walks and in this episode we discuss how ditching (not forever!) or reducing the amount of walks is an OK thing to do and could actually be a gift to your dog.

Say what?! Check out the latest podcast episode!

title: STAS: Lockdown Survival Guide
description:
The Sexier Than A Squirrel Podcast: Lockdown Survival Guide

We are diving into solutions and surviving lockdown without any damage to our relationship with our dog or regression in our training. 

When the light is there at the end of the tunnel, we want you to come out of this safe, healthy, and happy - and that includes your dog too! 

We touch base on socialization (look for a more in-depth episode coming soon!), controlling the controllable, and how to navigate the changes that are occurring with optimism and resilience. 

We delve into how homeschooling can provide such a quality experience as is evidenced by the enormous amount of people we are seeing have an amazing time with their dogs in our Worldwide Sexier than a Squirrel challenge!

title: How you tackle Failure
description:
Dogs deal with failure in different ways, as do we. The thing is, how we tackle failure has an impact on our dog. When we encounter failure and show our dog it뗩 an adverse outcome, we can trigger in them frustration, loss of motivation, and grit, leading to pessimism and other negative emotions. A once optimistic dog can quickly become a pessimistic one when failure is all they know. 

When we use the Gamechanger method, we can prevent our dogs from believing that failure is terrible by rewarding the outcome regardless of whether they뗬e got it spot on or not. This goes against what were taught by rewards-based dog trainers who would have us do differently. 

Watch the video for a full explanation of why rewarding what we do want and ignoring what we don뗪 want is an approach that does more harm than good.

You뗣l learn:
 How your dog's routine impacts their whole psychology & physiology

 What to do about it. With simple techniques to teach your dog how not to get excited over every little thing.

title: Kayl McCann & Bee-Line - UKI Ontario Fall Cup 2021 - All Runs
description:
I뗤 a little late with posting my Fall Cup recap, but it뗩 been a busy week and it took me almost the whole time to recover. Lol. 

It was SO nice to be back in the environment competing with my bestest girl and to be back around the Agility Community.  

The courses were very challenging!  But so fun.  I must say, after almost 2 years of not competing I felt RUUUUUSSSTY!  So very rusty.  I made lots of little mistakes and about half way through the day I was ready for a nap. Haha.  It뗩 crazy how much mental game can get weaker after so much time off competing.  

I was really happy with how Bee competed. I wish I had been a better handler for her.   Luckily of the 8 courses, I did well in the 4 that mattered.   

We earned:

游끥 Overall Top Reserve Dog - 16 Champion

游볞 Games Biathlon Overall  - 1st place
- Gamblers - 1st place 
- Snooker - 4th Place 

游볞 Master Series Overall - 1st place. 
- Jumpers - 1st place 
- Agility - 2nd place. 

游볞 Biathlon Agility - 1st place 
Biathlon Jumpers - E but loved the run! 

游눛 Thanks to the amazing McCann Dogs Agility Crew & Students.  Everyone looked fabulous out there! I was a very proud coach!  My voice was gone by the end of the day Sunday from cheering!   Congrats to everyone!! 

游뗿游낖 A huge shout out to Hannah Chambers and Shannon George for their work as sponsorship coordinators.  We got some great competitor bags complete with a cute bandana (That Funkee Monkee showed off all weekend) made by Need Some Sun 仇.

title: Ep7: Part 1: A Conversation with Jaakko Suoknuuti ~ Dog Agility Podcast
description:
We are so pumped for this 2-part conversation with the great JAAKKO SUOKNUUTI from Finland.  We feel VERY lucky that he agreed to join us on our Podcast as it뗩 not normally his jam. But we promised wine, laughs and Agility talk and he couldn뗪 resist. 

We set out to speak about understanding course paths but we went off in all kinds of wonderful directions! 

Jaakko Suoknuuti is an accomplished Agility Handler & Coach who is widely respected in the Sport of Agility. He & his partner Janita Leinonen are the creators of the popular handling methodology OneMind Dogs. They've both been a part of Team Finland for many years and earned many world championship titles. 먝

Jaakko and Kayl met back in 2012 and became fast friends. Kayl spent many years traveling to Finland to train and Jaakko would travel to Canada to coach the McCann Dogs Agility group. 먝Jaakko has the unique ability to see an Agility course from the dogs perspective which gives him the ability to teach, handle, design courses and coach students at a whole new level. 먝

In Part 1 of this 2 part podcast, We discuss with Jaakko, the many facets of becoming a better handler for our dogs by understanding what our DOG needs from us as we navigate a course. We're going to share with you the concept of "CCC" - Connect, Commit & Cue which are the 3 steps that have to happen between every obstacle on course!

Be sure to check out Part 2 (Launching July 2, 2021) where we continue to deep dive into the best ways to walk a course, REALLY knowing & understanding your dog and the life changing topic of "Lead Changes". You don't want to miss it!

Listen on all podcast platforms: www.McCannDogs.link/AgilityPodcast

title: Ep5:  Jumping Issues In The Dog Sport Of Agility - Dog Agility Podcast
description:
Jumping Issues...... there are all kinds of them in Agility.  Some natural and some influenced by the handler.

Don't forget to subscribe to the podcast so you never miss an episode: www.McCannDogs.link/AgilityPodcast

Welcome to the McCann Dogs Agility Podcast with your hosts Kayl McCann and Jamie Moreau. title: Bee-Line runs France World Team Tryout Standard Course
description:
Train with Kayl Online: www.Patreon.com/mccanndogs

Bee-Line and I trained on this Standard Course from Austrian Judge, Wolfgang Tieber.  This course was from the France Team Tryouts in 2018.  It was a fun one, but I wasn뗪 a fan of the DW approach.  I chose to set her up as best I could but had to sacrifice my position at the end of the dog walk.  OH, the joys of a running dog walk. Lol.   That jump at the end was actually super sneaky.  The dogs naturally want to come off to the right and miss the jump.  Thank god for verbals!!! 

Bee was happy to play agility but was NOT impressed with wearing undies.  Poor dog, I could have choose less obvious ones.

title: Our 1st Seminar - Kayl McCann & Bee-Line
description:
If you've been seeing my FB over the last few months, you've probably noticed that my life has had some heartbreak. This past weekend has helped me kick that sadness in the butt! 

This seminar was supposed to be focused around Rad (with a little a bit of Bee training). With this being my first "Agility Event" since losing Rad, It was hard at times to realize that I can no longer run Agility with him. But I can honestly say that this weekend I laughed and smiled and felt more happiness than I have in a long time. SO many things & people contributed to this.... The "boys", my friends, the environment and my special freckle face girlie.

I reached out to friends, Dave Munnings & Dan Shaw (From England) last year and asked them to come teach a seminar as I was really wanting to continue my personal education & growth in Agility. I knew they would bring something different and would give me some great idea's to build into my training. I also knew they were fun..... but I had NO idea that we would connect like we did. A weekend that was supposed to be about training Rad and focusing on Agility turned into a whole weekend of recovery and growth. 

Bee-Line had to step up to the plate and boy did she surprise me! She picked up new skills so quickly and I felt a whole new bond grow between us. Gosh, I love that little dog. I can't wait for our journey! 

I want to thank both Dave and Dan for sharing their knowledge & passion for the sport. They worked their butts off for us and brought a level of energy I rarely see from Instructors. We are a tight family here at McCann's and I can speak for all of us when I say that these boys have kicked our passion for the sport up a notch! 

I really- really appreciated the opportunity to be a student this weekend and to allow myself to just sit back and learn. I had so much fun both making mistakes and celebrating progress. I also LOVED experiencing the seminar with my friends & students. The positive vibe all weekend was so contagious. 

The time spent with D&D between the seminar days was quite possibly my favorite time.....not to take away from Agility lol... but I feel like I've made friends for life! The amount of inside jokes we created in 3 days is almost unbelievable. 

My heart is so full - I'm so grateful to the boys, to this crazy sport of Dog Agility and to the McCann Clan for helping me get back to myself. I had happy tears at the end of the seminar - lol - I'm turning into a suck! 

I hope you enjoy our Seminar Highlight Reel!

description:
Finally got a chance to edit video and time to write a post that Dave Munnings and Dan Shaw deserve仇勇 

Thank you, thank you, thank you for an incredible week(end) of Agility and all things hilarious.  We were seriously cut from the same cloth and I don뗪 think there are many people that can handle the ridiculousness of the McCann Group.  You both fit in like you뗬e been with us forever!  You guys were able to deliver some informative information to help everyone up their game, all while making it fun and comfortable.  Not all coaches have that quality.  We adore you both! 

The seminar was a huge success (I didn뗪 expect anything but....) but our time outside of the seminar was equally enjoyable to me.   SO many fun memories created. See # below 游땍. Ken and I absolutely loved having you guys.  

To my students: I뗤 very proud of our Agility Student Group.  Youre talented, determined supportive of each other and best of all, have a positive attitude!  You can뗪 beat the vibe at a McCann Seminar! 鮫봺잺

Being an Agility coach myself, I don뗪 take the opportunity to be a student enough. It뗩 so refreshing to turn off my teaching brain and just focus on myself and my little dog.  This seminar experience has once again, sparked my excitement and passion for this sport.  

2020 - lil 游냏 and I are coming for ya 游눩游낕驕뢣릞

title: Teaching Tough Weave Entries - Video Example of Dec 2 Lesson with Coach Kayl McCann
description:
Join the McCann Coaching Club for training inspiration, access to my weekly lesson plans and a monthly live video lesson!  https://www.patreon.com/mccanndogs

#trainsmart 

My in-class students and online coaching club students are working on a really tricky weave entry this week! 

I thought it might be interesting to show my short training session with Bee that j had tonight.  She had some struggles.  I think it뗩 important to break things down in order for the dog to find success WITHOUT doing too many repetitions.  Turn the volume down because I go CRAZY when she finally gets it! 游녠

I worked for only a couple of minutes on this skill and gave her a break.  I want to the let the lesson sit in her 游 for a bit. 

游 Stay tuned for tomorrow뗩 session when I try to put the weave entry back in sequence, at speed - with independence! 

游눩游낕游냏 

...........Weave entry session - Part 2

Last night I posted a video of Bee 游냏 and I working through some tough weave entries.  I broke it down and gave her a clear idea of what I was looking for.   Then I left it at that - Short & Sweet! 

Tonight I did another 2 min session.  I started with a little reminder so that she knew what to expect and then I really challenged her!  

With solid foundation, good timing and clarity in my expectation, we worked through this in 2 training sessions which took less than 5 minutes total. 

So much fun!

These are drills from my classes this week (both in house & online).  I took inspiration from a course from the US Open last month.

title: Kayl & RAD - ALL RUNS -  Canadian Open 2017
description: RAD is our 3 year old BC.  I just started running him earlier this year and we are now starting to gel as a team.  This competition was by far the best glimpse into the future we have with this dog!  Rad had a few clear rounds,  being the only dog at his height to complete the gamble within the time limit....... and winning 1st place in the Speedstakes Event.  HOWEVER, some of my favourite moments were from the courses we got eliminated in!  My goal for the weekend was to run him like I do in practice, to try my training and enjoy the ride.  I am even more encouraged to continue training hard after this weekend.  I can't wait to see what is in store with this young, talented dog.

title: Rad & Kayl McCann - Road to Nashville P1- Jan 2017
description:
My goals for young Rad this year is to qualify for Cynosport World Games.  He is just 3 years old and I've been consistently working with him for about 6 months now.  He belongs to my husband and was initially meant to be his agility dog.  Since he's so busy, I've taken over his training and have been working hard to develop some more skills and teamwork.  This is our 3rd trial together. 

We ended up earning a Team Q, Challenge Biathlon Q, Master Challenge Standard Q and a Grand Prix Q towards our goal to compete in Nashville at the 2017 Cynosport World Games.

The future is bright with this boy - still lots of work ahead of us, though ;)

description: Understanding and being able to read lead changes from your dog on course can be helpful in giving handling cues. title: Happy Valentines Day Ken (2015)
description:
I've received so many amazing music video's from you... I think it's time that I make one for you :)  I don't have a clue how to use all your fancy equipment, but I do know how to steal your guitar & how to keep it a secret ;)  Lexi was amazing and starting learning the song when she got home.  We were on a bit of a time line to get it done, but I'm really happy with the outcome. 

I really hope you like it!  This song really makes me think of our relationship.  I love the lines...

Baby Ill be loving you until we're 70 and my heart will still fall as hard at 23.
People fall in love in mysterious ways, maybe it's all part of a plan
Me, I fall in love with you every single day
When my hands don't play the strings the same way, I know you will still love me the same.
Your heart could never grow old, it's ever green.

Take me in to your loving arms, Kiss me under the light of a thousand stars, place your head on my beating heart.

Im thinking out loud - That I love you! :) Happy V Day!!!

title: Funkee Monkee & Kayl McCann WAO 2014 (Italy)
description:
Back in 2013, Funkee & Kayl won gold in every event at the WAO.  This year she returned to the WAO, this time in Italy, to defend her title.  Kayl had no idea it would be such a battle! When arriving to Italy, Kayl suffered from allergies, a chest, nose & eye infection & a hurt foot. She was physically & mentally exhausted from competing at the IFCS the weekend before in Netherlands.  With the help of her amazing little All Canadian "Funkee Monkee" & many other forms of support - Kayl was able to win many of the individual classes and earn the Bronze medal in the Pentathlon event!  What a ride.

To learn more about Kayl & her dogs visit: www.KaylMcCann.ca

title: Grand Slam & Kayl McCann - IFCS 2014 (Netherlands)
description:
Kayl McCann & Grand Slam compete at the IFCS World Championships in Netherlands for Team Canada.  This is Kayl's 9th World Championships, but Slam's first time on the world stage as he is only 2.5 years of age.  Their teamwork prospers over this incredible weekend and they earned 2 gold medals for Canada.  Grand Slam earned the 2014 IFCS Snooker World Champion title as well as the 2014 IFCS Biathlon World Champion.

For more information on Kayl & her dogs: www.KaylMcCann.ca

title: Hippy Shakes first Agility Show!
description:
Our demonstration team the "Purina Pro Plan Dog Stars" did some entertainment shows at a festival called WOOFSTOCK in May 2014. I decided to try Hippy Shake on some of the courses just to gain some experience. I haven't finished teaching her all the obstacles, so I made up my own little course patterns for her BUT it was such a great opportunity to get her exposed to all those distractions.  She seemed to get more confident with each show! Fun little dog! 

To learn more about Kayl & her dogs visit: www.kaylmccann.ca

title: OneMind Dogs - Challenge 4 Boomerang from Kayl McCann!
description:
Kayl McCann from Ontario Canada designed a new OneMind Dog Challenge based on the set of from the No.4 Challenge released this month! The challenge is to attempt the sequence with your dog using several OMD Techniques.  The course is not to be walked ahead of time - the challenge is trying to be successful on the first attempt of running it with your dog.  This will test your understanding of the techniques, your mental focus & your ability to execute the moves!  For each jump you complete successfully you will receive 1 point (A possibility of 6 points!)

To learn more about Kayl McCann visit www.KaylMcCann.ca & to be a part of the OneMind Dog Pack visit www.OneMindDogs.com.

title: IFCS ONLINE TEAM FUNDRAISER!
description:
www.dogsport.org/ifcs/

Want to train with the team?  For a small donation to the team you can have full access to the exclusive team member area.  This is a restricted area of the site where all the National team members are assigned International style drills and sequences to try and run.  They are also required to videotape their efforts, and upload their videos so that all team members can learn from each other.

1.    Auditor: can view courses / sequences and videos
2.    Participant: can view courses / sequences and videos and post 1-2 videos a month for critique by the team.

By analyzing the other members' performances, and getting feedback from teammates, the National team members can try out different handling styles/work to tighten up certain sections, problem solve particularly challenging sections etc.

For a one time $50 fee you can access this restricted area as an auditor; to download the sequences yourself, and audit the comments and videotapes that the National Team members have uploaded.

For $100 you can receive FULL access and can upload your own videotapes of the sequences to see how you measure up, and get feedback on your videos from the National team members!

All proceeds go to help the AAC National team in their efforts to get to the Netherlands to compete in the 2014 IFCS World Agility Championships.

title: Kayl McCann & Grand Slam - ONE MIND DOG - Agility Poetry in Motion
description:
Kayl McCann works her 2 year old Border Collie "Grand Slam" through courses designed by Janita Leinonen & Jaakko Suoknuuti using the revolutionary ONE MIND DOG methodology.  The method is based on carefully thought out techniques that can make even the most challenging agility course look like poetry in motion. 

Kayl is a member of the Canadian Agility Team with her dogs Ping Pong, Jitter Bug, Slyce, Funkee Monkee & now her young male - Grand Slam.  She has earned 30 medals for Team Canada & has been competing internationally since 2004.  

To learn more about Kayl or to book a seminar - please visit www.KaylMcCann.ca

title: 8-BALL
description:
To: My Baby Sis "Lexi Lou"

 I wanted to give you the opportunity to see 8 Ball any time you want!  I had lots of fun making this for you & Eighty was sooooo excited to help me make it.  He was in his glory getting to do all those tricks & some agility.  We both miss you soooo much, but know that he is doing well here & we are taking really good care of him for you!

I love you & miss you like crazy!

From: Kayl

* This is 8-Ball my little sisters Border Jack.  Last Year, she moved away to Jasper, Alberta to work at Jasper Park Lodge.  Unfortunately she can't have 8-Ball with her just yet, so in the mean time he is home here with us in Dundas, Ontario.  I thought it would be cute to do some training with him & make a video for her to watch anytime she was feeling homesick.

He's a pretty fun loving boy!  Enjoy :)

title: Fly Brave - learning dogs accurate jumping
description:
What if I fall?
 Oh, but my darling, what if you fly?

Brave flying dog training 九걾잺

I like this exercise a lot from many reasons cause it teaches many great things (without putting excessive stress on the body):

俱뫮잺 it teaches dogs to be brave and feel good in the air
俱뫮잺 apply the right amount of force to clean the jump (accrued landing)
俱뫮잺 improve horizontal force production - needed for long strides and long (flat) jumping on straight lines and running dogwalks 
俱뫮잺 can be done in small spaces, doesn't require extra equipment (anything soft and heavy enough it's fine)
俱뫮잺 very easy to progress/regress if needed, many variations available - you can add spins, vary start position, add bar between (hold in your hand), add toy catch.

title: Decin 2015 - Czech AWC Quali
description:
Decin - Czech Quali, 190 dogs in L class, great place to warm-up :-)
In each run, one of us made a mistake, if it were clean, we would be on podium in all of them! 
I'm so in love with Kite's performance - consistency, focus, mental stage, skills level...
7 months away from running and any fast movement, back in training 3 weeks ago. Entire core & stability workouts &mental games paid off sooo well! Enjoy your life back Kite!

title: EuroCup 2013 - Kite & Raider all runs
description:
Weekend Summary:
Saturday A3 (agility + jumping): Raider - 3rd place, Kite 2nd place (1st place Silvia&Bu) 
On Sunday Raider won A3 category
Grand Prix (all 6 runs from both day) Kite - 3rd place, Raider 4th place.

I didn't expect that we manage to go to EuroCup but "physio magic" works pretty well and finally we were able to compete. 
We've never tried running agility on the beach - so Raider and me constantly had mobility problems and Kite living up to her name (Kitesurfing) and she easilly flying over sand and set pretty cool times and get me into serious trouble in CACIAg agility 
Results: we finished 11 out of 12 runs, Kite won LA3 ex aequo with Silvia&Bu, Raider was 4th, on J3 Kite did her dis and Raider was 6th (1 bar), on CACIAg Jum Kite set the best time with 2 bars and Raider set pretty cool time with 1 bar down.
On Sunday in LA3 Raidet took 2nd place, Kite 1 bar and slighty slower than Bi, in J3 Raider 6th oplace, Kite bar and again 2nd time after Bi. On Agility CACIAg Kite finised on 3rd place nad Raider on 4th place.

title: Polish Championship 2013
description:
Raider become a new II Vice Polish Winner :-)
Total weekend summary: 2x 2nd place, 1st place, both dogs finnished on 3rd place total - Kite on Saturday, Raider on Sunday.
On Saturday Raider did a great job (2nd place in jumping), would be better if I remember the courses well and not push him to the wrong jump in agility run :)
Kite was running very nice,  2nd place in agility and in jumping she "pops" out of a weaves. Anyway, Alen set so nice courses ;-) that even with that mistake we took 3rd place in Saturday.
On Sunday we had Polish Championship.
On agility run Kite did amazing job, winning that run, Raider end at 4th place. 
And jumping...ehhh.... we had so nice run with Kite till she pops from weaves.... this is not in Kite style at all, she always had been very consistent with her weaves performance. Pity, but I loved our runs!

title: EO 2013
description:
Our very first  in life European Championship were quite successful. We managed to run some pretty nice runs and quali 2 dogs to final.
Kite ran wonderfully, two clean runs in ind., dis in agility team, nice jumping team run with seven best time and bar. Unfortunately dis at the last jump in the finals. Pitty, but anyway, it's a nice feeling, that with not a perfect run with bad handling decision, we were quicker (till the wall) than Cayenne, which finished the course of the 4th place.
Thanks for a great event and hope to see you next year!

title: Disability people & agility
description:
Agility can be great to disability people and ensure people of all abilities are reaching their true potential. 

Agata & Atos train with me over a year know. 
First months we spent on Agata's ability to remember more than 5-6 obstacles and I was learning how to be better coach for her. Then we was working on her body awareness. Now this is really looking nice :-)

Being able to provide support to Agata and coaching her is an incredibly rewarding experience

title: Follow Me! Handling without hands
description:
Pretty challenging course, 29 obstacles.
This exercise will help you to effectively cue dog to perform the all type of challenges.
Running without hands is a great way for handlers to understand how to use motion, legs, eye contact and arms when handling a dog. 
Running and turning with hand behind your back is a great way to teach handlers keep a nice balance and stay on feet.

title: Agility Dog Independence and Layering. Spam 8 months.
description: We've had so much fun in our agility foundation training working on independence and layering. This is a video that shows off some of the things we've done, and explains the process.
caption: false

title: Puppy Agility Dog Learning Threadle
description:
Border collie puppy Spam is 8 months old and has started to learn her "in" cue 마 verbal cue for a threadle on a jump, that pulls her to the inside of the jump. We've done so much fun during the past couple of weeks that I decided to split it into a few different videos so that it's easier to follow  and more content for you. We're having so much fun with agility foundations training!

Here are some more links on her threadles:

First session: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pxIb6yAWSBM

Later sessions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yAryF87n5E8
caption: false

title: Agility Puppy Spam Starting Sequencing
description: Spam 7 months old has gone from shaping the jump to sequencing in two weeks. Follow the process in this video!

tags: ['border collie', 'puppy agility', 'clicker training', 'agility foundation training', 'agility jump training', 'agility tunnel training', 'border collie puppy', 'young dog agility', 'how to train agility', 'at home agility training for dogs', 'how to start agility training for dogs at home', 'verbal cues agility']
caption: false

title: Teaching agility tunnel to Spam 6 months
description:
Finally, Spam got to learn the tunnel. We started really easy and gradually increased the challenges. This video is all about her first sessions of tunnel training. But don't turn it off if agility isn't your thing  the things we do here are a really good model for anything you want to teach your dog. From shaping the behavior, adding distraction, adding a cue and getting the dog to listen to the cue even when other things are more tempting.

If you want to join Spam in learning all about jumps and tunnels for agility, check out this online class that starts on April 1st.

http://www.fannygott.com/agility-handling-foundations-online

title: Spam 6 months  Starting some agility!
description:
It's been a few weeks, but we're finally back with a new episode of Spam's puppy diary. This video covers a lot of things that we've done over the past weeks, like:

游륩pam's first jump grids
游륡umping into my arms
游륡umping onto my back
游륩pinning right and left
游륪arget training for running contacts
游률ntroducing the Treat & Train
游륫sing her tight left and right cues on trees
游륟erding sheep again 
游륙arking at imaginary moose, running away from training, getting lost in the woods, and much more fun 游뱑꽥勇

If you're interested in my online classes Agility Handling Foundations Online, Jumping Gymnastics, or Advanced Obedience Skills, check out this page: http://www.fannygott.com/online-classes

title: Puppy Spam's Road Trip Through Europe  I almost lost her twice!
description: Border collie puppy Spam is 24 weeks and this is a video about what we've been up to in our journey through Poland, Czech Republic, Austria, and Slovenia. She's gone from cute puppy to stubborn teenager, we're struggling with some herding behaviors, and we had two big scares where I thought I might lose her. She's also done a lot of great things and we're having so much fun on our trip so far.

title: TRAINING BORDER COLLIE PUPPY SPAM 16 WEEKS  When is luring good? Agility Puppy Training.
description:
This week, Spam and I have tried some luring in addition to our shaping and capturing. We've worked on:

- Weaving between my legs
- Position between my legs
- Lying on side
- Rolling over
- Lifting front feet
- Sit up from down
- Jumping stand
- Stimulus control

title: Border collie puppy Spam 15 weeks  Training my new agility dog
description:
Spam and I have had our first full week together, and we've made brilliant progress on many of the things that I wanted to work on. This video includes:

- Switching between two toys.
- Games to play with treats.
- Steadiness in sit.
- "Go" to toy on the ground.
- Circling a cone for tight turns.
- Crate Games.
- Nose touch to hand.

If you want to learn more about our way of training, please check out our new Foundation Class Online that starts on January 1st:

http://www.fannygott.com/foundation-class-2020

title: BORDER COLLIE PUPPY SPAM 14 WEEKS  Training my future agility dog
description:
Part five in Spam's puppy diary is here! We're finally united after having been apart for a couple of weeks. She's spent time with my friend Jessica Mann of motiveradehundar.se

This video shows some of the cool things that Jessica and Spam have been working on, as well as some exercises that I've started since I got back, like jumping into my lap and going around a cone for tight turns in agility.

If you'd like to see our two very first sessions on going around a cone, you can find them here:

title: CLICKER TRAINING EXPLAINED: Shaping, Capturing, and Offered Behavior
description:
In the first episode of Spam's puppy diary  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uJ4cjr86RnI  I talked about how my training is based on capturing, shaping and offered behavior. I뗬e realized that we might need to talk about those terms a bit so that were all on the same page. 

Link to the blog post about fixing problems with offered behavior: http://www.fannygott.com/how-to-fix-slow-reactions-to-cues

title: Clicker Training 8 week old border collie puppy SPAM
description:
Introducing SPAM! I'm so excited to finally have a puppy again. Spam is 8 weeks old and I want to share our training so that more people can be successful with shaping, capturing and offered behaviors. Puppy Spam will probably grow up to be an agility dog, so a lot of the training we're doing is going to be done with that in mind. However, I think anyone that wants to teach precise, fast and reliable behaviors will get a lot out of this. 

If you want to know more about offered behavior, capturing and shaping: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bk9xHpN4JB8

If you want to see longer versions of the training sessions in this video, you can check out these:

Capturing craziness: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUeP7A4bKj8

Roll over: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BsHCSlUqaOQ

Parking on a pillow: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2emlLBIOMa4

title: Bud 9 weeks
description:
Budis 9 weeks old and these are clips from our two sessions today. I haven't done any formal training with him since I made a video of his play last Monday. 

He is such a funny little puppy. Intense, persistent, happy and focused. 

I love this kind of training, where you get the chance to teach the puppy the rules of the game. I always want to make sure that my dogs chose to engage in the activity that I present, and this is the first step to that. 

Full videos of our sessions are posted in our online classes this spring. There is still time to join!

title: Agility Training Epic and Squid
description: My dogs are quite different, but also very much alike. Epic rarely takes a step off the "perfect" line or adds extra strides. He is very predictable, but sometimes takes the whole jump upright down in his efforts to be tight. Squid is crazy and runs with a higher frequency. She'll add some more strides and have some wider turns then Epic. In these two sequences, Epic had six strides less than Squid. But they were equally fast. They are both awesome in their own way.
caption: false

title: Foundations for down from heel
description: Once my dog can offer a down from a stand, I put it together with my backwards heeling to get an offered down from motion. Even if I have put a cue to the down from stand, I will still do this without a cue and then add it again while in motion. I don't let the dog offer the down from a forwards heel.

title: Agilityhandling
description:
P친 onsdag b칬rjar andra omg친ngen av succ칠n med grundkurs i handling online. 

Vill du ge din hund en klar f칬rst친else f칬r agilityhandling redan fr친n b칬rjan? Vill du sj칛lv f친 koll p친 hur man f칬r hunden runt banan och utf칬r olika byten? Vill du ha en sj칛lvst칛ndig agilityhund? Vill du kunna p친verka och f칬rutse hundens landningspunkt n칛r han hoppar?

Den h칛r onlinekursen passar dig som vill komma ig친ng med agilityhandling. Under kursen g친r vi igenom inl칛rning av sv칛ngar, rakstr칛ckor, framf칬rbyten och bakombyten. Vi arbetar med f친 hopphinder och tunnel. Kursen passar f칬r hundar fr친n ca 8 m친nader.

Har du och din hund problem med kommunikationen p친 agilitybanan? D친 kan den h칛r kursen passa 칛ven den lite mer erfarna hunden. H칛r f친r du tips om hur du kan g칬ra din handling tydlig f칬r hunden, s친 att han alltid v칛nder 친t r칛tt h친ll, f칬ljer dina anvisningar och anpassar sina hopp efter vart ni ska h칛rn칛st.

title: Teaching directed retrieve
description: This is Squid's first session in learning the directed retrieve. We're working on the part where she is running to the left or to the right on my hand signals. There is no retrieve involved, as I want her to learn the directions before I add the retrieve. We work on retrieving in separate sessions. She knew running around poles from before, and caught on to the idea of running left och right very quickly. I love obedience training where a good foundation make hard things very easy.

title: Squid training distant control
description: Squid and I have started to do some obedience training again after a long break. This is some training on distant control, where the goal is for her to change position on cue without moving her back paws at all when I'm 15 meters away. I have started to add the cues "bak" (sit from stand) and "upp" (sit from a down) and also use cues that she knows from before - "ligg" (down from a sit) and "st친" (stand from a sit). Two positions left to work on - down from a stand and stand from a down.

title: Squid's Running Contacts
description: I've started Squid's training on running contacts again, after a longer break during the winter. She has picked a different way of doing it and I'm not sure I like it. Both Shejpa and Missy would push off with their hind feet at the bottom of the contact most of the time. Squid will put her front foot in the middle of the contact and push off with her hind feet on the ground. It's so fast that I have a hard time seeing it when I'm training. Part of me feels that she should get to choose what ever technique she is happy with, part of me believes that the other way of doing it is both faster and easier to maintain. I don't really know what to do about it.
caption: false

title: G친sahoppet Agility Trial
description: Two runs from this Saturday. We're eliminated in the first run (she is supposed to go in the tunnel and not on the A-frame the second time). In the second run, we're clean and placed 2/71.
caption: false

title: Squid Weaving 2x2
description: I added a jump before the straight line of four weave poles today, and got a lesson on latent learning. Squid seemed to forget everything she knew about weaving when I added the jump and I was a bad dog trainer and my first session was way too long (maybe 4-5 minutes). She got a break, and for the next session, I made sure to set my timer on 3 minutes. In that session, her skills were back in place and she nailed 10 out of 11 repetitions. What a great lesson on what a break can do in your training, and on the importance of short sessions and evaluation.
caption: false

title: Squid Weaving 2x2
description: Four straight poles, different entries.
caption: false

title: Squid Weaving 2x2 - Problem Solving
description: After a few sessions where Squid really had trouble with entries from 10-11 o'clock, i decided to break it down and see if I could figure out where her trouble begun. This is video of all repetitions in two sessions today. Total training time was four minutes, but I have edited some playing out. It seems like she got it when I broke it down for her and she is now ready for more challenges on four straight weave poles.

title: Puppy Obedience (and some dogwalks)
description:
This is a video of Squid from the first obedience seminar she has attended. Today, we started to work more seriously on heeling and got to do our first short sequence in a trial setting. It is very important to start early doing sequences where the dog has to do a few things before getting rewarded. We did also split it up more and worked on entering the ring and focusing before the first exercise. 

I added some of the dogwalks I was working with Shejpa on at lunch as a bonus in at the end of the video
caption: false

title: Dogwalk Training with Shejpa
description: Trying to get in shape again for the agility season. I didn't have time to put up anything but the dogwalk, but she shows great understanding of criteria. I need to work on a "go on" cue though.
caption: false

title: Missy Agility Training
description: With Missy, I have realized that she is way to high on the arousal curve, and we need to adress that before we can solve any problems in obedience or agility. This is a video that shows one of our first sessions where my goal is to have a less aroused and more thoughtful dog in agility. Lots of Its Yer Choice games, no tugging, few repetitions on agility equipment and calm breaks if she makes a misstake.
caption: false

title: Shejpa's Winning Run in Standard Agility
description: Shejpa won standard agility (agilityklass I) and got her third and last leg in class I. She was clean and ran over 8 seconds faster than the second fastest dog. She might not look that fast, but she is! Dogwalk was crap, but I knew it was a gamble with almost no training for two months. Dogwalk was good in our team run, so I includet a clip of that as well. The rest of the team run wasn't very good. I wasn't as focused as I should have been, since our team was already eliminated.

title: Squid 17 weeks
description:
Squid has turned 17 weeks. These are some of the things we have been working on this past week. First clip is just Squid relaxing in her open crate while dogs are working around her and we're teaching (ok, I'm videotaping my puppy :D). Second clip is of Squid playing with me, listening to "sit" and "stand" command and also reacting to her "go see" command. She is a very social puppy :D

Next clip is of her starting to sit pretty, or at least, throwing her hands in the air. Very cute. Then hiding her nose in her paws and crawling.

Last clip is showing a challenge in stimulus control that we have been working on lately. She is supposed to nose touch repetedly to the palm of my hand, freezing her nose on the back of my hand and doing her puppy yoga if she sees the closed fist.

title: NKK Hamar 2008
description:
Shejpa's second weekend of trialing. She wasn't at her best, in heat and not in the mood at all. And I have to admit I wasn't the best handler either. Bad diagonal on the rear cross and bas positioning on the front crosses (and one where I really should have gone for the rear instead...). She was a good girl though and we got what we came for. Legs in both jumpers and standard. First place in jumpers and second place in standard. 

Also a clip of puppy Squid playing and showing her new trick in the arena.
